title: Introducing the $t$
question_text: Which of the following statements about the $t$ distribution is true?

choices.text: The spread of the $t$ distribution is less than that of the standard Normal distribution.
There is more area in the tails of the $t$ distribution than there is in the standard Normal distribution.
The $t$ distribution uses degrees of freedom and as they decrease they approximate the standard Normal curve more closely.
The $t$ distribution uses $\alpha$ instead of $\sigma$ to calculate a test statistic.
The $t$ distribution is symmetric about $0$, bi-modal, and bell-shaped.

solution:
Solution

The $t$ distribution is used to approximate the standard Normal distribution when the standard deviation of the distribution is not known. It uses an $s$ instead of a $\sigma$ to represent the standard deviation.

It has the same approximate shape as the standard Normal distribution but is more spread out at the tails. This spread, or area, increases as the degrees of freedom increase. These degrees of freedom are denoted by $df=n-1$. The larger tails mean that values farther from the mean are more likely in the t distribution. The t distribution is used more often when the sample size is smaller.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because the spread of the $t$ distribution is greater than that of the standard Normal distribution.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because the $t$ distribution uses degrees of freedom and as they increase they approximate the standard Normal curve more closely.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because the $t$ distribution uses $s$ instead of $\sigma$ to calculate a test statistic.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because the $t$ distribution is symmetric about 0, single-peaked, and bell-shaped.
